title: International Traffic in Arms Regulations: Exemption for Defense Trade and Cooperation Among Australia, the United Kingdom, and the United States
summary: The Department of State proposes to amend the International Traffic in Arms Regulations (ITAR) to support the AUKUS partnership among Australia, the United Kingdom, and the United States. This amendment introduces an exemption to the requirement for obtaining a license or other approval for the export, reexport, retransfer, or temporary import of defense articles; the performance of defense services; or engagement in brokering activities among these nations. The aim is to foster defense trade and cooperation, reflecting a commitment to shared security standards.
affectedParties: Defense industry entities in Australia, the United Kingdom, and the United States
Government agencies in Australia, the United Kingdom, and the United States involved in defense trade and cooperation
keyChanges: Introduction of an exemption for license or approval requirements for defense trade among Australia, the United Kingdom, and the United States
Specification of defense articles and services excluded from the exemption
Inclusion of a provision for intra-company, intra-organization, and intra-governmental transfers to allow for the transfer of classified defense articles to certain dual nationals
Revision of the section on expediting license review applications to include new processes for Australia, the United Kingdom, and Canada
exemptions_and_exceptions: Defense articles and services listed in a new Supplement No. 2 to Part 126 are excluded from eligibility for transfer under the proposed exemption
Transfers that would require certification to Congress pursuant to sections 36(c) and 36(d) of the AECA are excluded from the exemption
implementation_and_compliance: Transferors must maintain records of each transfer and make them available to the Directorate of Defense Trade Controls upon request
Authorized users in the United States, Australia, and the United Kingdom must meet their respective industrial security requirements
License applications for exports not eligible for the exemption must be processed within specified timeframes
implications: Enhanced security cooperation and collaboration with Australia and the United Kingdom
Potential reduction in licensing burdens for some exporters
Facilitation of defense trade among the United States, Australia, and the United Kingdom under shared security standards
additionalNotes: Public comments are invited on the proposed rule and its provisions until May 31, 2024
The proposed rule is part of the broader AUKUS partnership aimed at deepening diplomatic, security, and defense cooperation among the three nations
